To make progress towards consensus in future rounds, I believe a few adjustments could help:

1. We should each reflect carefully on our true "must-haves" vs. "nice-to-haves". Being crystal clear on our core needs will allow us to be more flexible on secondary issues.

2. When making proposals, we should strive to address the stated concerns and priorities of all parties, even if it means compromising on our own secondary preferences. Proposals that neglect any one party's core needs are unlikely to succeed.

3. In discussing proposals, we should focus on interests and objectives rather than positions. Openly sharing the "why" behind our preferences may reveal compatible interests and spark creative solutions.

4. We should remain patient, respectful and optimistic. Consensus often emerges gradually through a collaborative process of listening, understanding, and refining ideas. Even incremental progress is valuable.

5. If needed, we could consider bringing in an impartial mediator to help surface underlying issues and guide us toward mutually satisfactory solutions. Fresh eyes can sometimes break a logjam.

Those are some initial thoughts on how we might adjust our approach to improve the odds of reaching unanimous agreement in upcoming rounds. I'm open to other suggestions as well. The key is that we learn from each round and keep working together in good faith. I remain hopeful that a consensus agreement is within reach if we stay committed to the process.
